at ocw.mit.edu.
PROFESSOR: All right.

I'll go ahead and get started
in the interest of time.

We're talking about
holographic tomography.
And the next slide, please.

We can just glance
at the outlines.

But again, we'll
speed through this.
I know everybody's got class.
So what is Tomography?

George, I think tomos
means slice in Greek.

So it's basically
reconstructing an image

from cross-sectional
projections.

And this is an example
of a fan projection.

This is parallel
projection data.
Next slide.

So one of the key
elements in tomography

is forming this radon
transform property.

And that's for any projection
given normal to an angle theta.

It's defined as the integral
over the path length

gives you the projection
intensity of your object.
So next slide please.

That's related to the
Fourier slice theorem where,

again, if that projection
is done at an angle

and mapped into the
frequency domain,

that maps along a straight line
in the non-diffracting case.

So because of that and the
linearity of the Fourier slice

theorem, we can
reconstruct an entire image

and get a map in
the frequency domain

with discrete points due
to our discrete sampling
size of the projection.

So you can notice from this
though that it's very highly
sampled in the [? VC ?] region.

And out in the high
frequency region,
there's few data points.

So what happens, this
is the ideal case

where we like even sampling
throughout the distribution.

This is actually what we
collect with a discrete number
of pixels.
This is our filter.

So there's different
filter types

and what they do is they try
to weight the higher frequency
regions.

So we end up with a
nicely reconstructed image

without a lot of blurring
due to the high dependence
of the [? VC ?] terms.

So the different filter
types, the most common

is the ramp filter which weights
it in this wedge fashion.
There's a SheppLogan filter.

It's kind of like a
sinc [INAUDIBLE] cosine
and [INAUDIBLE].

Pay attention to
this cosine filter

because it drops off to zero
at the high frequencies.
You'll see that coming up.

So this example with
this complicated image

basically turning into
a transmission image

where black
represents an opaque.
White is transparent.

That's the standard
2D Fourier transform.

If we do projection
mapping and these are

different scan
angles you can see

that looking from bottom up, you
can almost pick out the image.

The MIT comes
through it sideways.

That's the projection
you get at 45 degrees.

Those are mapped directly
to the frequency domain,

as I depicted with the
Fourier slice theorem.
So next.

That radon transfer,
then you can
map for every projection angle.
That's here from 0 to 180.

And Matlab even has the color
scale bone which kind of
looks like an X-ray.
Go figure.
Next slide please.

So now we can reconstruct for a
limited number of projections.

So you can see in the case
where we take 10 projections

and reconstruct our image,
there's a lot of artifacts.

These are streaking, a lot
of noise within the image.

And as you go up in
projection number,

you get closer and closer
more accurate reconstruction
to your original image.

And then with a
different filter types,

this is the ramp on top,
cosine on the bottom.

You notice that I
mentioned the cosine filter

kind of attenuates the
high frequency terms

and you notice that
with the blurred image
in the final reconstruction.
So next.

We can also simulate
noise in the projection

like one might get in
a real application.

So that's noise in the
radon transform plots.

And then the reconstructed
image with different standard

deviation values
for the noise, you

can see a reconstruction
is noisier

and noisier up to
the point where

it's virtually indistinguishable
for high values of noise.
Next.

So another interesting
problem arises

is how many objects can you
detect with very limited
projection data.

You can see with a simple
square the radon transform,

which is also called
a sinogram-- forgot
to mention that.

But it's pretty
uniform throughout.

But if you have four objects,
if you take a limited projection

view, it might look
like two or three.

So that's something
in the application

that you need to take an
increased number of projections

to actually resolve here
your kind of defect.

So that brings us to
a standard object.

And this is a head,
MRI scan or CAT scan.

And that's a standard SheppLogan
head phantom, which is actually
implemented in Matlab.

And you can construct a radon
transform of that image.
Next.

You could actually look
at how many projections

you need to get in
order to get accuracy.

And this accuracy profile
we defined as the difference

in the actual reconstructed
image per pixel,

that magnitude squared divided
by the number of pixels.

And normalize that in
relation to the actual image.

So you can see right around
36 projections you get
a pretty good reconstruction.

You don't need a huge collection
of data for the simple phantom.

But in real life,
you obviously want

to maximize your projections
that you can collect.

[INAUDIBLE] is going
to talk refraction.

GUEST SPEAKER: So
I'll just catch up

a bit up on the
diffraction tomography

before we move on to
experimental results.

So right up to now, we've
just considered a plane wave
[INAUDIBLE] through an object.

And we're not considering
diffraction at all.

But lightwaves don't
behave that way.

So prediction that
we have is quite

different than just the line
integral which effectively
is the radon transform.

So analogous to what we have
in the earlier case which

was the Fourier slice
theorem, instead of mapping

a projection at a particular
angle where we are illuminating
it with an incident plane wave.

In the Fourier domain, the
transform of the prediction

maps onto a semi-circular
arc instead of mapping
to a straight line.

And the radius of
the semi-circular arc

is proportional to
the wave number.

So it's, in a way, dependent
upon the illumination
characteristic.

So just to show, so once we are
moving towards low wavelength,

we're just going towards the
earlier case where we end up

in the Fourier domain we're
mapping the projection
onto a straight line.

So like I just
mentioned earlier.
So if you change the--

in the earlier case, we
just changed the orientation

of the projections, I mean
we are changing the direction

from which we are
recording the projections.

And also we changed the
frequency of the illumination.

What we're doing is
we're trying to map

the information of the
object in the Fourier domain
along certain frequencies.

And the semi-circular arc,
in a way, as you can see,

we're mapping it
along a smaller disk.

So it's like a low [INAUDIBLE]
version of the original object.

And so from this
Fourier domain, you

can just do an inverse
transform to get
the information [INAUDIBLE].

So we'll just move on
to the fun part, I guess
PROFESSOR: Sure.
OK.
So we did a few experiments.

This first one was with
this little keychain object.

And what I did was just
suspend it and spin it.

And from that simple video,
we grabbed some frames.

Just assuming it's a
constant rotation profile,
which is wrong.
I know that.

But from that, we created
simple threshold image values

that were equivalent to
our transmission data.
And next slide.

So from that, we can
digitally reconstruct

from these kind of
vertical cross sections

3D slices of the projected
image and construct

a three dimensional
topography of our image.
Next slide.

So this is our reconstruction
of the little keychain.

And what's interesting--
I don't if the camera
can zoom in on this.
[INAUDIBLE]

There's a little white face
and some white artifacts
on this image.

And those come up on our
reconstruction as the holes

just due to the fact that the
threshold values were set such

that dark images were
set to be transmissive.

So another experiment we
did with the help of Laura

and her lab was looking
at transmission tomography

in the lab using a
[INAUDIBLE] light
source or white light source.

And we have in this
little test tube

some translucent gummy
candy, and then surrounded

by a sugar, trying to
get index matching that
was like a red fruit drink.
And all that's in water tank.
And the stage rotates.
So next slide.

So from that we
collected 36 projections,

one every 5 degrees
around 360 degrees.
Or no, 180 degrees.
I'm sorry.

So these are our
collected images.

And I just had a little
video [INAUDIBLE]..
So anyway, next slide.

We can reconstruct that as well
and get these horizontal slices
of a reconstructed image.
This is a different color map.
That's Matlab's colormap set.

And that's similar
to what an MRI

operator might see looking at
slices through somebody's body.

That's our reconstructed
fan of projection data.
Next.

And here's our 3D
reconstruction.

And what's
interesting to note is

that we are able to
reconstruct, actually, not

only the gummy object
but the little air

bubbles that don't really
resolve in this picture.

So we thought that was
really interesting.

So the main use for
this, obviously,

is medical and
biological cat scan,

computerized actual tomography,
and then other uses.

This is actually a
cell where they're

looking at the internal
structure on its nanoscale.
Next slide.

And then in the
material science field,

they're using this
more and more.

This is electron tomography
looking at the p-n doping
of a silicon cell.

And then that's a materials
crystallography exercise

looking at the kind of
nanostructure materials.
And last slide.

So the diffraction
effects, we didn't really

get to experiment with because
it's somewhat difficult.
It's kind of a cutting edge.

And that becomes an effect,
as [INAUDIBLE] mentioned,

when the material
you're trying to resolve

is on the same order
as the wavelength

that you're
illuminating it with.

You can see for these different
projections going across

and then over, they're
different distances,

projection distances
of the receiving
end of their apparatus.

So you could see more
and more diffraction
as you propagate further.

And similarly with
the upper right case,
that's a little tungsten wire.

So the reconstruction takes
into account digitally

the diffracted pattern
and subtracts that out.
So with that, any questions?

AUDIENCE: In the
gummy bear picture,
why was so much of it missing?

PROFESSOR: Well, can
you go back to that.

GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah
the [INAUDIBLE]..

So what we did was
we just had two lumps

of candy placed at
two different places.

And that's what
we were trying to.

We ideally wanted to
get the original shape
of the gummy bear.
But it wouldn't stay the same.
PROFESSOR: Yeah.
I was actually broken up.

It was broken up to
fit into the test tube.

And also, it took some time
to create the projections.

So it started dissolving in the
sugar water, almost digesting.

GUEST SPEAKER:
There was a problem
of it floating in the medium.

So we just stuck it to
the side of the test tube.

AUDIENCE: Why did you
have to put it in water?

Was it just to show
like what you'd
do in a medical application?
PROFESSOR: Sure.

Laura suggested that we try
to use an index matching

fluid so we don't get
the lensing effect.

And go back to the
projections really quick.

You can sort of see
right here that it

was forming in [INAUDIBLE]
within the candy.

So we were getting kind of
a spherical lens formation.

GUEST SPEAKER: We
were illuminating it
with a different colored light.
So that's one reason, as well.
PROFESSOR: Yeah.

There was a green filter
on the white light source.

And we put it in red fluid
to get maximum contrast.
AUDIENCE: OK.
Thank you.
